item.title: Monroe County Hoopers
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded:
Throughout this off-season, the Prep Girls Hoops staff will be taking a close look at some of the top underclassmen across all of Ohio’s 88 counties.

Monroe County is named for James Monroe - for U.S. Secretary of State and President of the United States. When the area was formed, it was actually a part of the state of Virginia, only to be succeeded to West Virginia and the Union during the Civil War. Monroe County is now on the Eastern border of Ohio. It is one of the least populated counties in the entire state.

Let’s take a look at a number of talented underclassmen from Monroe County.

[caption id="attachment_52580" align="alignleft" width="200"] Ashlie Louden is already over 1000 points at Beallsville. (Photo Credit: Times Leader Online)[/caption]

Ashlie Louden - 5'5 Guard - Beallsville - Class of 2020

Louden does a little bit of everything for Beallsville. She is a true point guard with outstanding court vision - routinely creating scoring opportunities for her teammates. She is also an outstanding rebounder - at just 5'5 - from her lead guard position. Ashlie scores the ball at a high level, already over 1000 points for her career. She shoots a high percentage from all 3 levels, as well as the FT line. Alli Long - 5'8 Forward - River - Class of 2020 Over her career at River, Long has been a relentless rebounder - averaging close to double-digit rebounds for her first 3 seasons. Alli has double-double potential each night that she steps on the court and will probably reach those numbers during her senior year as she turns into one of the key offensive players for her team. She has a high motor and is very physically tough. Her effort and energy makes everyone better around her. Kalista Friday - 5'2 Guard - Monroe Central - Class of 2022 Friday bust onto the scene as an effective guard for Monroe Central during her freshman season. Although she is young - Kalista often plays with the confidence and maturity of a seasoned vet. Her lack of size does not hurt her as a scorer - she averaged double figures and shot over 40% from 3-point range, while also dishing out a handful of assists each night.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Who are some of the top underclassmen in Monroe County?

item.title: High School Summer Ball- Standouts from the Snohomish High School Tournament
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: High school summer ball started this last weekend and we were there to cover the annual Snohomish tournament. Many of the top teams in the state (Eastlake, Kentridge, Glacier Peak and Woodinville) were there to compete in this first high school tournament of the summer. The first-place seeds from pool play ended up being Kentridge, Arlington, Glacier Peak, Burlington, Lynnwood, Interlake and Kamiak. Glacier Peak (in the bright pink uniforms) took home the trophy after a nail biting victory over Arlington (30-28). Some standouts from this weekend that will be big prospects in the near future were from the Arlington program. Keira Marsh (2022), Hailey Hiatt (2021) and Jenna Villa (2023) are a dynamic trio that will be tough to stop this summer. Marsh, a 5’5” guard averaged 8.5 points on the weekend. Hiatt poured in 31 points in four games and shot 92% from the free throw line (11/12). Villa, only an 8th grader, had a big weekend for the Eagles. She averaged 7.5 points and 6 rebounds per game. The 6’1” guard/wing has an extremely high ceiling spends countless hours working on her fundamentals. Villa is also one of the top performers for the Tree of Hope -Loyd (2023) Nike team. She will be one to watch as she will likely be a big-time recruit. [caption id="attachment_54983" align="alignright" width="300"] Glacier Peak, photo credit: @glacierpeak_gbb[/caption] Another name that should be well known in the basketball community as being a humble, yet fierce competitor is Mia Hughes, the KingCo MVP, Woodinville Falcon (2021) and WAY TO WIN-Gold standout. Hughes is only 5’10” but can play with the best of them. She is a mature player in that she knows how to use her fundamentals to battle down low or she pull it out and drain a beautiful three pointer. She is also hard to guard because she runs the floor in transition and has great court sense. She will be a tough matchup this summer and will be in the mix to get some votes for MVP again in her high school season. Another shout-out goes to the lefty point guard, Grace Moawad, from Liberty High school (2020.) Grace helped her young, 2A team, go 3-1 this weekend. Their only loss was by two points to Kamiak. Moawad averaged 18 points per game with a game high 25 against Kings. Grace is a competitor and she knows when to turn it on and take her defender off the dribble or reign it in and get her team under control. You can tell this is her year to shine. Her efforts in the offseason are showing on the court. Don’t forget to follow us on Instagram (@phgwashington) and on Twitter. We will be covering the Edmonds-Woodway tournament this weekend.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Who stood out in high school action last weekend?

item.title: NEO 3 on 3 League - Five Takeaways from Week #1
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: As June progresses - HS basketball teams in Ohio are working hard to develop chemistry and improve with sights on the 2019-2020 season. There are a number of shootouts and leagues that coaches and players take advantage of. One of these leagues is the NEO 3 on 3 league. A rare non 5-on-5 setting, this 3 on 3 league has proven to be valuable and a good indicator of future success for some of the state's top teams. Week #1 of the NEO 3 on 3 league was held at Wadsworth High School and we have 5 takeaways from that first night of games - which featured nearly 150 match-ups for HS/College teams from all divisions. Elyria Catholic looks to be strong again. A final four team in 2017-2018 and a regional runner-up in 2018-2019, Elyria Catholic needs to replace the production from departing seniors Faith Williams (Gannon University) and Regan Schill (Baldwin Wallace). If you watched them at Wadsworth during week #1 of the NEO 3 on 3 - it sure doesn't seem like this will be a problem. Led by the Winnen twins, Abby and Ally, Elyria Catholic displayed an inside-outside game that carried them to a dominant 7-0 record against a very difficult schedule. On the night, Elyria Catholic defeated Ohio Dominican University, Marietta College, New Philadelphia, Hiland Red, Shelby White, Mount Union University and West Holmes. Chippewa lost a lot to graduation - but is ready to reload behind Celina Koncz. Chippewa - the Wayne County Athletic League champion in 2018-2019, who made a run all the way to the state final four - graduated a number of contributors (Grace Lindquist, Kierra Amelung, Bailey Clark, Bailey Ferrell), but seem primed for another outstanding season. Two-time All-Ohioan Celina Koncz and 3-point marksman Taylor Thomas are back for the Chipps and they played very well during week #1 of the NEO 3 on 3. Chippewa - who had an upperclassmen team (7-0 on the night) and a freshmen team (5-2 on the night) look deep and skilled, yet again. Shelby has the potential to be even better than last year. Shelby, who ended their 2018-2019 season with a loss in the district semi-finals to Willard - are back and have the potential to improve on their 22-3 record. Youngstown State commit Emma Randall (pictured above - photo credit: Richland Source) leads the way for a Whippets squad that is now battle-tested and features a number of outstanding role players - including Sydnie Seibert, Haylee Baker, Olivia Baker, Sophia Niese - among others. They finished 6-1 on the first night, with their only loss coming at the hands of Mount Union. It doesn't matter who is playing - Wadsworth basketball always seems to get the job done.  Unfortunately for veteran head coach Andy Booth - his Wadsworth Grizzlies have battled a number of injuries during the past 5 seasons. That hasn't stopped the Grizzlies from reaching the state final four on a number of different occasions and ultimately winning the state championship in 2016. With health in mind and a few of Wadsworth's top players (Taylor Leatherman and E'Anna Won) on the mend - the Grizzlies had one of the youngest teams in the building on night #1 of the league, but still finished with a flawless record of 7-0. Keep an eye out for Maggie Long, Stephanie Andrews, Riley Shriver, Ky'Sonna Won and Regan Simpson the next few years. We would not be surprised to see another Suburban League championship and long post-season run for the Grizzlies this winter. The Wayne County Athletic League should be as deep as ever during the 2019-2020 season. In addition to the previously mentioned Chippewa Chipps, the WCAL performed at a very high level during week #1. Smithville, Norwayne and Waynedale all finished with winning records at 5-2. Sarah Meech and Taylor Depriest are back as 4th-year letterwinners for the Smithies and their experience is evident when you watch the green and white play. Norwayne is led by the DeMassimo sisters - Caitlyn and Taylor - as well as sharpshooter Olivia Stanley. Waynedale and their 3-headed monster at guard of Brooklyn Troyer, Kelsey Wolfe and Laney Murphy is primed to make a run at their 1st WCAL championship in over a decade. Throw the Dalton Bulldogs into the mix and the WCAL should be one of the most exciting small-school leagues in all of Ohio.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What did we learn from the first week of games in the NEO 3 on 3 League?

item.title: NWO 3 on 3 League – Five Takeaways from Week #1
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: As June progresses – HS basketball teams in Ohio are working hard to develop chemistry and improve with sights on the 2019-2020 season. There are a number of shootouts and leagues that coaches and players take advantage of. One of these leagues is the NWO 3 on 3 league. A rare non 5-on-5 setting, this 3 on 3 league - a spinoff of its sister league, the NEO 3 on 3 league - has its own share of quality teams and talent. Week #1 of the NWO 3 on 3 league was held at Willard High School and we have 5 takeaways from that first night of games – which featured over 80 match-ups for HS/College teams from all divisions. Mansfield Madison has the potential to be much improved.  With a group of girls that have achieved major success in soccer, volleyball and girls track - basketball at Madison has hovered around the .500 mark over the past few seasons. This winter could finally be the time that the Rams take the next step and contend for an Ohio Cardinal Conference championship. Led by Chesney Davis and Kari Eckenwiler - Madison had a great showing on the first night of games, finishing 4-3 against a quality schedule. Willard has a "new" coach and the same talent.  After longtime bench leader Jon Dawson stepped away at the end of the 2018-2019 season, one in which Willard advanced to the district championship - many wondered who would step in to guide a squad with a lot of promise. The Flashes didn't have to look too far - hiring long-time Willard coach Barry Pfahl. The former head coach of 19 years in the district - Pfahl is taking over a team led by All-Ohioan and 1000 point scorer Cassidy Crawford - pictured above. Willard started their summer off with a bang, picking up right where they left off last season, running through the league with a 7-0 record in their home gym. Wynford is experienced and it shows.  Amy Taylor-Sheldon has enjoyed some success during her time at Wynford, so it's not like she was doing cartwheels with her team's 15-8 finish last winter. With that being said, Wynford should be cautiously optimistic as they head into their next campaign. They did lose leading scorer Olivia Grove, but she was the only senior from that 15-win team and the returners - led by Rylee Aslpach - looked outstanding on their way to a 7-1 finish during the first night of competition. Cardington is showing no signs of slowing down.  Cardington has been 84-16 over their last 4 seasons, on their way to 4 straight conference championships. They have had a number of skilled players come through the program - so you would think that as they lose a few more players to the college ranks - Kynlee Edwards (University of Findlay), Taylor Reppart (Heidelberg) and Paige Clinger (Mount Union) it would tough to maintain that level of success. What we learned is that Cardington has even more talent coming to compliment All-Ohio post Casey Bertke, who will be a college athlete in her own right upon graduation. Beth Hardwick really shined during the first night of games. We should expect another outstanding Bellevue-Margaretta match-up.  In last year's Sandusky Bay Conference crossover match-up, Bellevue - one of Ohio's top teams in division II - and Margaretta - one of Ohio's top teams in division III, played to a classic in front of a sold-out crowd. Bellevue won 58-54 in overtime and although both teams lost some key players - they have a lot of production back. Margaretta will be led by All-Ohioan Jayden Moore, as well as Taylor Malson and Elliana Schaefer. Bellevue returns Casey Santoro and Cory Santoro - two of the state's top scoring guards.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What did we learn from week #1 of the NWO 3 on 3 League?

item.title: SD State Track MVP's DOMINATED by Hoopsters
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: Coaches often advocate multiple sports' participation, so the 60% rate of SD all-state GBB-ers (29 of 48) performing at the State Meet last weekend impresses us. In fact, 5 of 6 female MVP's were ballers in the winter season, led by 3-event winners, Caelyn Valandra-Prue of White River & J.C. Pulse of McCook Central. Class of 2020 Pulse won both Hurdles, the 200, and finished 2nd in the 100m dash. Junior JC plays high energy defense on MCM's consecutive State Tournaments teams, averaging 11 pt, 6 rebounds and 3 assists at the 2019 State. Athletic and improving, Pulse is a rising college prospect, featuring maturing skill sets. Sophomore CVP of White River won the 100, 200, & 800; but missed a FOUR-BAGGER by 0.02-sec in the 400. Wowzer!! CVP is a first team Class B All state wing, [caption id="attachment_56177" align="alignright" width="300"] 2010 State Track MVP Photo courtesy of SacredHoops.com[/caption] racking up huge numbers at State B's, avg 22-ppg, 6 boards, and 3 assists.   Motivated,intense and 100% Lakota, she has upside growth ahead in both sports to collegiate levels. Senior Shaylee DeBeer of Deubrook won the Class B Field MVP, winning the triple jump, & 300 hurdles, plus legs on championship 4x400 & 4x800 relays. Her BB exploits led Deubrook to a 2019 SD 16 berth. Rapid City Stevens' Elizabeth Schaefer excelled in three sports, winning Class AA Miss Volleyball last fall, and playing guard on the Raiders' winter run. In hoops, she led a 7th seed team to the consolation championship. The Augustana track commit just wins - five consecutive years in the 300 hurdles, 3 years in the 100 hurdles and ran on the 4x400 relay. Elk Point-Jefferson's Kenna Curry was bright spot for Huskies' hoops, controlling the paint. Her senior year was capped with the Class A Field MVP award for her discus triumph and shotput efforts. Trio of Sees' Sisters from Avon running on same relays - Great Family - Alexa-Courtney-&-Lauren (Augie BB commit) .  At the standard set by Sully Buttes' Weinheimers, Bradfords, & Guthmillers! GBB observers (and coaches) await summer ball and anticipate the HS season for strong improvements from track speedsters like Cerrington Jones of New Underwood, Miller's 3-sport standout Kadye Fernholtz, Avery Broughton from Corsica, Yankton's Madison Wuebben, Julia Weber of Bridgewater-Emery, Emily Breske, Bearcat , and MVP's Emily Fox.  Great BB adventures lie ahead; other sports & summer ball PLUS purposeful practice hit the sweet spot for PGH recognition. Year-Round Strength & Flexibility Conditioning minimize injuries . Keep swishing ...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 of 6 State Track MVP's Won by Hoopsters

item.title: NWO 3 on 3 League – Five Takeaways from Week #2
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: As June progresses – HS basketball teams in Ohio are working hard to develop chemistry and improve with sights on the 2019-2020 season. There are a number of shootouts and leagues that coaches and players take advantage of. One of these leagues is the NWO 3 on 3 league. A rare non 5-on-5 setting, this 3 on 3 league – a spinoff of its sister league, the NEO 3 on 3 league – has its own share of quality teams and talent. Week #2 of the NWO 3 on 3 league was held at Galion High School and we have 5 takeaways from that first night of games – which featured over 80 match-ups for HS/College teams from all divisions. Seneca East may once again be the team to beat in the N10.  Seneca East won 20 games last year and they were the top team in week #2 of the NWO 3 on 3 League. Jessica Bowerman is one of the N10's leading scorers and Emily Siesel and Bailey Hamilton are part of an outstanding supporting class. A week #2 finish of 8-0 has Seneca East at 12-3 entering week #3. Avery Coleman's continued development is going to be key for Lexington's improvement. In an era dominated by guards and post-players who would much rather be labeled as a "stretch 4" or a "face-up 5", a true back-to-the-basket post player can make a big difference, especially at the high school level. Avery Coleman has shown flashes of dominance at Lexington. As LHS standout Jessica Brokaw takes over the program, she will be relying on Coleman to get some easy baskets around the rim, to go along with her nearly 12 rebounds a game from last season. If Lexington can get 15-16 points a night from Coleman, they have the potential to surprise some people in the OCC when Gabby Stover is healthy. Ontario will go as far as Carleigh Pearson takes them. Ontario has only won 3 games through the first 2 weeks of the super-competitive NWO 3 on 3 League. It's clear that 5'7 guard Carleigh Pearson is going to have to carry the Warriors on the offensive end. The 3-sport standout can score in a number of ways. Whether she is driving hard to the rim and finishing with either hand or showing an impressive amount of range on her perimeter jumper, Pearson will always draw the opponent's attention - she is going to need to have some big games to put Ontario in the "W" column more often than not. Mansfield Christian has some solid young players to build around in the near future. Mansfield Christian - a team that has struggled during the past few seasons in the Mid-Buckeye Conference - is showing signs of growth. Led by 2-year starter - athletic junior guard Elle Schmitz - Mansfield Christian has a large freshman class that enjoyed some success in junior high. Although it may not necessarily show up in the win column this year, MCS has added athleticism skill that they haven't had in recent memory. With Courtney Pifher graduated and headed to college - Buckeye Central still has plenty of talent. Combo guard Taylor Ratliff - pictured above, scoring wing Claudia Pifher and long post Lexi Evak lead the way for a very talented Buckeye Central squad that shows no signs of trouble in replacing star-graduate Courtney Pifher and key contributor Elizabeth Heydinger. Buckeye Central finished week #2 with a 4-4 record, but enters the final week of the regular season at a 10-5 clip.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What are five takeaways from week #2 of the NWO 3 on 3 League?

item.title: NEO 3 on 3 League – Five Takeaways from Week #2
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded:
As June progresses – HS basketball teams in Ohio are working hard to develop chemistry and improve with sights on the 2019-2020 season. There are a number of shootouts and leagues that coaches and players take advantage of. One of these leagues is the NEO 3 on 3 league. A rare non 5-on-5 setting, this 3 on 3 league has proven to be valuable and a good indicator of future success for some of the state’s top teams. Week #2 of the NEO 3 on 3 league was held at Wooster High School and we have 5 takeaways from that first night of games – which featured nearly 150 match-ups for HS/College teams from all divisions. This is an all-time special group at Berlin Hiland.  The past two seasons, Berlin Hiland has been eliminated in the DIII state tournament by McDonald's All-American Jordan Horston and eventual state champion Columbus Africentric. Horston is gone now - headed to The University of Tennessee - but nearly all of Hiland's roster returns and this could be the year that they bring home another state title. Bowling Green commit Zoe Miller, standout guards Brynn Mullet - pictured above and Morgan Yoder and a host of other Lady Hawks give legendary coach Dave Schlabach one of his deepest and most talented rosters ever. Hiland has two teams in the NEO 3 on 3 League and both of them went undefeated in week #2 with 7-0 records.

Loudonville looks a lot different - but they can still win a bunch of games. 

The 1000-point plateau is one that special scorers reach in high school girls basketball. It is extremely rare for a team to have 2 1000-point scorers on the same team. During another 20-win season in 2018-2019, the Loudonville Redbirds girls basketball team had 3 players reach the 1000-point career mark. Two of them are gone, as Nikki Weber is heading to Malone University and 1st-team All-Ohioan Celeste Ryman is headed to Clarion University. However, Emily Seboe is back and joined by her twin sister Annie Seboe, as well as experienced juniors Grace Vermilya and Sydney Snyder. Hoban has a new coach and a lot of questions to be answered. Thousands of basketball followers across the state of Ohio were shocked to hear the news that Pam Davis was leaving her post at Canton McKinley to become the new head coach at Archbishop Hoban in Akron. Hoban, who finished their regular season undefeated last winter and ended up losing to powerhouse Wadsworth in the district semi-finals, has a lot of new faces at the varsity level, where they will need to find an identity for their new coaching staff. They finished 4-3 during week #2 of the 3 on 3 League. Karli Anker is really good - Manchester could win the PAC this year. Karli Anker is one of Ohio's top guards in the Class of 2021. Through two seasons, she has already scored nearly 1000 points. In a 3 on 3 setting, she has so much room to show her array of moves off of the dribble. She commands double-teams and does an outstanding job of creating scoring opportunities for her teammates. As Manchester returns a number of solid role players around Anker - including Chloe Perry, Haley Webb, Bri Brown, Abby White and Emma Stamperd - they should compete for a PAC championship in 2019-2020. Orrville has to replace their entire lineup - expect them to get better as the year progresses.  Not only does Orrville have to replace their long-time coach Mark Alberts Sr., also need to replace a senior class that made-up the entirety of their line-up during their back-to-back PAC championship runs in 17-18 and 18-19. New bench boss Maggie Davault does have an outstanding wing to start with in Tamara Turner, as well as a heady guard in Amari Slaughter to build around. There is a lot of athleticism on the Red Riders squad - so as they learn Davault's system and become more comfortable in it, we can expect some big wins down the stretch.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What are five takeaways from week #2 of the NEO 3 on 3 League?

item.title: NWO/NEO 3 on 3 League - Five Takeaways from Week #3
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: As June progresses – HS basketball teams in Ohio are working hard to develop chemistry and improve with sights on the 2019-2020 season. There are a number of shootouts and leagues that coaches and players take advantage of. One of these leagues is the NEO/NWO 3 on 3 league. A rare non 5-on-5 setting, this 3 on 3 league – has its own share of quality teams and talent. Week #3 of the NEO 3 on 3 league was held at Shelby High School and Week #3 of the NWO 3 on 3 league was held at Ontario High School and we have 5 takeaways from that first night of games – which featured over 200 match-ups for HS/College teams from all divisions. The double-elimination tournament to conclude the league will be held at Berlin Hiland on 6/24, featuring 40+ HS teams and nearly a dozen D2/D3 college teams from the state of Ohio. Emma Brown is healthy and she is ready to lead Copley to a winning season. Copley finished Week #3 with a 6-1 record in the NEO division - one of the top performances on the week. Emma Brown is clearly the leader of Copley's team and after a challenging winter during her junior season - where she missed a lot of time due to a severe concussion during an early-season game - she has shown in June why she is one of Ohio's top 3-point shooters. The Santoro sisters will once again give Bellevue one of the state's top backcourts. Bellevue finished the regular season of the 3 on 3 league with the top record from the NWO division. Their 7-0 Week #3 performance and 20-3 overall record were in-large part due to the efforts of the Santoro sisters. Kent State bound Casey Santoro and her sister Cory Santoro (pictured above) - a superb 2021 guard in her own right - can score the basketball at will and do an outstanding job of playing off of each others' penetration. Because of their guard play, Bellevue is an early favorite to win the HS division tournament at Berlin Hiland on 6/24. Taylor Malson is going to become a household name during her junior season. Malson was a 1st- team all conference selection last winter for the state-ranked Margaretta Polar Bears. Although they were missing a number of their "top" varsity-level players, Malson led Margaretta to a 6-1 record during Week #3, where she earned Player of the Week honors and was often one of the top players on the court. He mix of size, speed and athleticism blend well with her skill level - making her a very tough match-up for opposing defenses. With six graduated contributors and a number of teams focusing their defenses on Jayden Moore - Malson could put up some huge offensive numbers this year. Revere is going to be an intriguing team to watch during the 2019-2020 campaign.  Playing without standout Adison Novosel, Revere finished week #3 with a 6-1 record. Led by 5'5 guard Taylor Kenna, Revere looked especially quick off of the dribble. They had outstanding depth at Shelby and although they are relatively young compared to other teams in the league, the future looks very bright for Coach Dan Brown's group. There are a number of teams that can walk out of Berlin Hiland as the champions of the NEO/NWO 3 on 3 League. One could argue that although there are outstanding 5 on 5 leagues in the state of Ohio, the tournament at Berlin Hiland will have the largest collection of top teams in one spot in the summer of 2019. The HS portion of the tournament includes Bellevue, Margaretta, Berlin Hiland, Wadsworth, Hoban, Elyria Catholic, Chippewa, Loudonville, River Valley, Dalton, Smithville, Norwayne, Waynedale, Pleasant, Shelby and Buckeye Central - along with over 2 dozen other squads. The college bracket features Ohio Dominican, Ashland, Walsh, Malone, Mount Vernon Nazarene, Marietta, Mount Union, Baldwin Wallace and Muskingum. It will certainly be a "who's who" of talent for girls basketball players in the state of Ohio.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What are 5 takeaways from Week #3 of the NEO/NWO 3 on 3 League?

item.title: Coca Cola Classic: Top Backcourt Performers
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded:
High school-aged talent from throughout California was on display at the Coca Cola Classic in Whittier, Calif. on June 15-16. Orange County-based Athletes for Christ took home the high school Silver division title with an undefeated weekend, while the Central Valley Hornets travelled traveled down I-5 and beat all comers to earn the Bronze division title. Below is a closer look at some of the top guards we saw at the Coca Cola Classic:

Nikki Villanueva, 2023, Athletes for Christ (Yorba Linda HS)

Villanueva may have been the best all-around player in the tournament. She displayed a high-motor throughout the two days while both running  the offense and serving as an overall pest on the defensive side. Perhaps her biggest strength is the ability to break down a defense and either get to the rim. or find an open teammate. The young Villanueva needs to extend the range of her jump shot, but she’s already a strong finisher with a solid mid-range game. She was the best player on what was the tournament’s best team.

Keinaiya Moore, 2021, SoCal Buzz (Warren HS)

An argument could also be made for Moore being the best player in the tournament. She brings excellent size and strength to the point guard position, which poses immediate problems for opponents. Her length and solid frame allows Moore to either pass or shoot over smaller guards, or to easily back-them into the post and go to work from there. With the ball in her hands, she plays with a noticeable poise and coolness that leads to few mistakes.

Catryna Marquez, 2022, Central Valley Hornets (Cerres HS)

Marquez made her mark through a combination of smooth athleticism and gritty competitiveness. Offensively, Marquez showed the ability to score from anywhere on the court. She is also more than willing to crash the offensive boards.  Defensively, Marquez proved to be equally as adept. She has excellent feet as an on-ball defender, but perhaps even most noteworthy are her defensive instincts. She proved disruptive all weekend by filling passing lanes and picking pockets.

Mia Rodriguez, 2022, Central Valley Hornets (Cerres HS)

With Rodriguez and Marquez (above) in the backcourt. Cerres High School in the San Joaquin Valley has a promising pair of guards to work with the next three years. Rodriguez impressed onlookers with her offensive game. Most notably, the dual threat she bring of either getting to the rim or hitting a perimeter jumpshot. Rodriguez showed to be a very patient offensive player. The indelible image of the weekend was seeing her calmly probing the defense on the wing, and then either slashing to the rim or creating space for an open jumper.

Monse Garcia, 2022, Pass it Forward (West Adams (HS)

Garcia flashed classic point guard skills while serving as the undisputed floor general for Pass it Forward. The slightly-undersized, sophomore-to-be made her teammates better all weekend with excellent court vision and a deft passing touch. While Garcia is not a dynamic scorer, she did show good shooting range by hitting multiple 3-point shots.

Julianna Conklin, 2022, Athletes for Christ (Canyon HS)

Conklin largely hovered around the wing offensively and proved to be an adept mid-range and 3-point shooter. But perhaps even more impressive were her overall basketball instincts. Conklin was constantly breaking up passes on the defensive end and seemingly grabbing every loose ball. She is the type player where the box score doesn’t truly reflect her overall impact.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: High school-aged talent from throughout California was on display at the Coca Cola Classic in Whittier, Calif.

item.title: Oregon City- EOT Standouts and Players to Watch
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: End of the Trail (EOT) in Oregon City is the host of some of the most prestigious tournaments in the Northwest.  The End of the Trail -Shootout was this last weekend (June 28-30th) and the End of Trail- National Showcase tournament is this upcoming weekend (July 5-8th). Both weekends have a plethora of talented teams that travel from as far as Hawaii, Alaska, Idaho, California and Washington. We were there to preview some of the standouts from this last weekend as well as some notable players and teams to watch this coming weekend. Myana Calloway (2023) from Nike Team NW (NTNW) and Liberty High School, is a hard-working player that spends countless hours in the gym training. She is the true definition of a gym rat. As an incoming freshman, Calloway saw a lot of minutes on her Liberty team. Facing some opponents that were three to four years older than her, she demonstrated that she is a strong ball handler and is fierce defender. She was able to single handedly change the tempo of the game. She will be a key player for the Lady Patriots as wells as NTNW. Lily Whitehead (2023) plays for NW Basketball Academy and Bothell High. She is a fierce defender that runs the floor well on transition D and then quickly communicates to her teammates to make sure everyone is with their correct match-up.  She shoots the ball well and has a strong fundamentals. Maddie McMahon (2020) plays for NW Basketball Academy and Edmonds-Woodway High School. She is a 5’10 wing/small forward that was MVP her sophomore year. She is a tough player that is good on the boards and instinctually moves well without the ball. Kaimyla Nolen (2022), plays for Tree of Hope- Pacific 2022 and is a new transfer to Kentwood High School. She had a standout season as a freshman and was named first-team all-league. She averaged 14 points and 5 rebounds per game and was selected to play in the 2A/3A All Star game. Kaimyla is a strong and physical guard that can shoot the quick jumper, or penetrate and kick for the assist. She has a very high basketball IQ in which she can control the game or put her teammates in the right positions to be successful. She is also a strong defender that can defend a quick guard or battle with the forwards. Make note of Kaimyla--she is a great all-around player that can confidently play multiple positions.   Kaylee Cooper (2022) a 5’4” guard from Sumner High is a lightning fast player that can play defend the best of them.  She can also score when needed. Kaylee is very good transition offense and defense and has a beautiful three-point shot. Torree Thomas (2022)  the 5’9” Fife High School and TOH-Pacific 2022 small forward/wing that is a highly skilled and versatile player. She can bang down low to score or she can hit from the three-point line. She thrives on controlling the boards and does a great job in transition offense. Thomas is also a player that is good off the ball but can also create opportunities for herself. Meagan Karstetter (2022) the 6’1 small forward from Moses Lake, and the Way to Win program is a confident player that demands respect. Not only is she is a physical player,  she can also turn it on and control the tempo of the game. She instinctually crashes the boards on offense and defense.  Her ability to play high and low makes her a tough matchup. Malia Ruud (2025) is only entering the 7th grade but will be a big-time player in the next few years. The 6’0” post from NW Heat currently wears a size 14 men’s basketball shoe. At the EOT Shootout, she averaged 20 points and 20 boards per/game and helped her NWH team make it to the championship game against Bay Area Blitz.   Ruud is a dominate player who doesn’t get distracted when defenders foul her and she has the innate ability to take her time and finish at ease. When she does go to the foul line, she shoots over 90 percent free-throws. Tree of Hope – Team Loyd (2024) won the entire D2 bracket (High School ) as incoming 8th graders as they faced off against a fierce Colfax Falcons (California) Team. The TOH team is stacked with talent and is consistently playing up at least two or three grade levels to find competition.  Mo Hines, also the coach of the 17U Tree of Hope EYBL team,  dedicates his time to developing the best players in the state.  Some notable names to watch on this 2024 team include, Katie Fiso, Devin Coppinger, Kate Wooten, Maya Davis and Nancy Ferguson, and Ava Smith.   We will be there to report on the EOT National Showcase tournament this weekend.  Be on the lookout for standouts from FOH, NW All Starts, Clutch Red, Spokane Stars, KMBA Seattle Elite, Way to Win, Pacific U17 and Tree of Hope 15U.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: EOT Standouts and Players to Watch

item.title: Fayette County Hoopers
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded:
Throughout this off-season, the Prep Girls Hoops staff will be taking a close look at some of the top underclassmen across all of Ohio’s 88 counties.

Fayette County is named for Marquis de La Fayette – a French general who took the side of the colonials during the American Revolutionary War. Fayette was a large influence in the French Revolution as well. The area was formed in the early 1800's from pieces of Highland County and Ross County. Although there are only a few high schools in Fayette County, girls basketball programs from both Miami Trace and Washington Court House have enjoyed their fair share of success over the year.

Let’s take a look at a number of talented underclassmen from Fayette County.

Shaylee McDonald - 5'7 Guard - Miami Trace - Class of 2020  Shaylee McDonald had an outstanding junior season, one in which she earned all-district honors for the Miami Trace Panthers. McDonald will be a 4-year letterwinner after her senior season. She is known for being a pesky on-ball defender and a very hard worker. Shaylee has the potential to take over a game offensively - don't be surprised to see the bulk of the offense run through her during the 2019-2020 campaign. [caption id="attachment_64022" align="alignleft" width="214"] Rayana Burns is an explosive guard for Washington Court House. (Photo Credit: Pinterest)[/caption] Rayana Burns - 5'9 Guard - Washington Court House - Class of 2020 Burns is a super-athletic guard on the hardwood, who also is an elite competitor on the track, where she has been a state placer. She causes havoc on defense, getting a number of steals and deflections and does an outstanding job of creating easy scoring opportunities for her teammates. Burns is at her best when she is getting two feet in the paint and attacking the rim. Shawna Conger - 5'8 Guard - Washington Court House - Class of 2020 Conger is an off-guard with a knack for scoring the basketball. Whether it be with her feet set off of the catch or creating her own shot off of the bounce, Shawna is a tremendous shooter from all 3 levels of the floor. She also does well at finishing through contact around the basket. Conger's length makes it easy for her to get her off shot whenever she wants, but she can also create for her teammates. Gracee Stewart - 5'5 Guard - Miami Trace - Class of 2021 Stewart was one of the county's most improved players last winter. A full-time JV players a freshman, Gracee burst onto the scene during her sophomore year, providing a legitimate perimeter threat for her team. Stewart has great range on her jumper and although she is more effective right now as a stand-still shooter from deep, she has a lot of promise as a true combo-guard moving forward.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Who are some of the top underclassmen from Fayette County?

item.title: Highland County Hoopers
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded:
Throughout this off-season, the Prep Girls Hoops staff will be taking a close look at some of the top underclassmen across all of Ohio’s 88 counties.

Highland County is home to a number of popular recreational areas, including Rocky Fork State Park, Paint Creek State Park, The Fort Hill State Memorial and The Fallsville Wildlife Area. The hilly county divides the Little Miami and Scioto Rivers. Highland County is home to 5 different school districts and some traditionally-strong high school girls basketball.

Let’s take a look at a number of talented underclassmen from Highland County

Kayla Burchett - 5'2 Guard - McClain - Class of 2021 Burchett helped McClain increase their win-total by 10 wins last winter. For her efforts, she was named to the OPSWA DII All-Ohio team, certainly a tremendous honor for a sophomore. The lead guard is a good 3-point shooter, but also does a solid job of using her quick first step to get to the rim - where she can finish either hand. Despite her small stature, she is a good defender. [caption id="attachment_64037" align="alignleft" width="294"] Samara Cannon scores the basketball at a high rate. (Photo Credit: The Highland County Press)[/caption] Samara Cannon - 5'6 Guard - Fairfield - Class of 2021  Samara Cannon plays with a lot of confidence - and rightfully so. Cannon is an explosive scorer, who scores a majority of her points off of the dribble. She has an old-school game, often-times using a jump-stop and two foot finish, whether it be with a legit jumper or an impressive floater/runner package. Samara is a good passer with outstanding court vision. Strong and physically tough, she plays like an ideal combo-guard. Zoe Fittro - 5'7 Forward - Lynchburg Clay - Class of 2020 Somewhat of a tweener, Fittro comes in the slasher mold. She can knock down the open jumper - even out to 3-point land - if she is open, but is much better as a driver/play-maker. Zoe is an active defender - especially off of the ball - where she creates a lot of turnovers and easy transition baskets for her team. She is a tough kid who averaged double figures during her junior year as a compliment to Peyton Scott. Karleigh Hopkins - 5'7 Guard - Hillsboro - Class of 2020 Hopkins is great in the open-floor. She has a strong build that helps her effectively play and finish through contact. A reliable 3-point shooter with a quick release, Karleigh shows signs of being a dynamic scorer, but does need to develop a more consistent toolbox when it comes to creating scoring opportunities for herself. She is a solid ball-handler.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Who are some of the top underclassmen from Highland County?

item.title: Class of 2023: Who is ready to make their mark?
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: Just as the 2022 class before them, the Class of 2023 in Southern Illinois is plentiful with talent and skill.  There is balance and versatility in the Class: plenty of guard play, plenty of posts, and plenty of scoring potential.  I will breakdown the top 10 players in the area that I have seen develop over the last couple of years. This group of talented young players are no doubt ready to make their mark on the Varsity level and will turn heads of fans and recruiters alike as they enter the High School scene in the State of Illinois. Gracie Heckert: 5’8 Guard  Beecher City HS Indiana Flight West Gracie is a gifted combo guard that has the ability to score in multiple ways as well as take the lead as point guard.    She is a dependable 3 point shooter and her strong physical frame helps her finish at the rim with consistency. Her court vision and basketball IQ are excellent and are two of her biggest assets. Emily Konkel: 6’0 Guard Teutopolis HS  Indiana Flight West  What sets Emily apart from the next player is her length...she is a very long guard/wing.  She is reliable from mid range and in the lane, with a developing 3 point shot that is very promising.  Ball handling and shooting at her size is an exception not the norm. Emily’s skill level as a guard is quite impressive.   Her potential will draw plenty of interest on the recruiting trail as she hits the circuit next season with Indiana Flight West. Addie Wright:  6’0 Post Oakwood HS  Indiana Flight West Addie is an athletically strong post.  She runs the floor very well and is a plus rebounder/defender.  Addie can use either hand to score inside and has range to 15 feet with a very soft touch.  Her potential is very evident and has already piqued several recruiters interest heading into her first varsity season. Trinity Tingley:  5’5 PG Paris HS Indiana Flight West  Trinity is the prototypical point guard.  She is a leader on the floor, running the offense and setting the tone defensively.  She is equally good spotting up with a jumper from the 3 point line or finishing in the lane.  She excels at pushing the ball up the floor and leading the break. Her court IQ is a big plus for her team.  Coaches will love her work ethic and competitive spirit. Kendra Young: 5’11 Guard Paris HS  Indiana Flight West  Kendra is a shooter.  She is very confident and will pull the trigger when open and in her range...which is well beyond the 3 point line.  Her near 6’0 frame makes her difficult matchup for many teams. She has developed a drive and slash portion to her game that will make things even more difficult for opponents.  Recruiters will take notice with her combined length and shooting ability. Alycia Triplett: 6’0 Post Charleston HS Indiana Flight West Alycia is a Post player with loads of athletic ability.  She is unmatched at her ability to run the floor and excels at rebounding, especially the offensive end.  She has a very soft touch in and around the lane. Her game is just taking off and has already shown up on recruiters radar. Kaylee Niebrugge: 5’9 Guard, Teutopolis HS  Indiana Flight West Kaylee is strongly built guard/wing who has the ability to play both inside and out.  Her floor game is an asset as she frequently will make an impact in a variety of ways: as a defender, rebounder, scorer, and ball handler.  Her versatility is a major plus helping her to be a threat to score at multiple levels. Savannah Orgeron:  5’11 Post Mahomet HS  Heart of Illinois Savannah can play multiple positions going inside against other post players, as well as going outside to play on the perimeter.  Her physical size, strength combined with her ball handling skills and shooting touch create matchup problems for teams. She has demonstrated a nice feel for the game utilizing her passing ability and exceptional court vision.   Rilee Riggs: 6’2 Center Mt Carmel HS Indiana Flight Blue Rilee has excellent size and a frame.  She has the ability to score in the lane with either hand displaying a soft touch.  Her length and frame are a plus as she is capable of effecting the game on both ends of the floor with her rebounding and defense.  As her skill level increases over the next few years, so should her stock. Deming Hawkins:  5’8 Post Paris HS  Indiana Flight West Deming is small post player with a large heart.   She has a motor that does not quit, enabling her to make plays that many others simply don’t or can’t.  Over the last year she has progressed from a back to the basket post player to a more perimeter oriented player.   This added flexibility makes her a valuable asset to her team. She is not only a playmaker, she is a smart playmaker.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Get to know a few prospects that are sure to be household names soon!

item.title: Welcome to Prep Girls Hoops Texas
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded: Welcome, Texas girls basketball players, coaches, families and fans, to PGH Texas! We couldn’t be more excited to launch a website that will work tirelessly to bring exposure to talented Texas basketball players of ALL levels. If you’re a prospect with a shot at playing at the Division I, Division II, Division III, NAIA or junior-college levels, we are here to cover you and help bring exposure to your game. The Prep Girls Hoops Network, is a fast-growing national brand aimed at providing visibility and coverage for high school girls basketball players at all levels. We don’t rest once the high school basketball season is over. We’ll be covering: prep season, spring AAU season, summer high school ball, summer AAU, fall ball and more. In short, if basketball is happening, we’re covering it. Here’s just some of what you’ll get as a subscriber to PGH Texas: — Recruiting Reports. Interviews with basketball prospects of all levels, available to hundreds of coaches who are subscribed to our network throughout the country. — Event coverage. If there is a bigtime tournament or showcase happening, PGH wants to be there. — Game analysis and evaluation. — Weekly preview stories. — Extensive grassroots coverage. We hope that you’ll subscribe to Prep Girls Hoops Texas and find out what in-depth, round-the-clock coverage of the state’s basketball scene really looks like! — The Prep Girls Hoops team

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What's can you expect from PGH Texas?

item.title: PGH Texas: The Rankings
item.dc:creator: prepgirlshoopsstaff
item.content:encoded:
We’ve put a lot of time, thought and networking into building our player rankings. Prep Girls Hoops Texas is excited to unveil the most comprehensive prospect rankings, including all high school classes in the Lone Star State. These prospect rankings have been compiled by our staff with input from high school, club and college coaches from across the state. Players are ranked on their status as a college prospect. Note: These rankings are just the beginning. We work to make them as accurate and comprehensive as possible, understanding that once the players take the floor the next night, things are bound to change. Our aim is for these lists to be the start of the conversation, not the end of it. We want to provide visibility to as many players as possible, growing the game in Texas in the process. The next step is simple: We’ll be in the gym watching games the rest of the winter and throughout the grassroots season to add names and update the lists 3-4 times each year. We’re excited for you to join us. We’re thrilled to continue to immerse ourselves in the Texas basketball scene to further develop these rankings in the years to come. With that, we present for our subscribers the Prep Girls Hoops Texas Player Rankings.
